binGuide.title: What are you throwing away?
binGuide.subtitle: Select a category or search for an item.
binGuide.noResultsHint: Try checking your spelling or using a different term.
binGuide.endOfList: You've reached the end of the list.

error.permission: Camera permission was denied. Please enable it in your browser settings to use the scanner.
error.noCamera: No suitable camera found on your device.
error.unidentified: The item could not be clearly identified. Please try again with a clearer picture or search manually.
error.title: Analysis Failed

error.noGeolocation: Geolocation is not supported by your browser.
error.addressFromLocation: Could not determine address from your location.
error.allowLocation: Please allow location access to use this feature.
error.selectAddress: Please select a valid address from the suggestions.

contact.title: Contact & Feedback
contact.subtitle: Have a suggestion or found an issue? Let us know!
contact.name: Name

success.title: Thank you!
success.message: Your email client has been opened to send your feedback.

notConfigured.title: Feature Not Available
notConfigured.message: The contact feature is not configured for this app version.

disclaimer.content: The information provided by this app is for general guidance only. While we strive to keep the information up-to-date and correct, we make no representations or warranties of any kind, express or implied, about the completeness, accuracy, or reliability. Any reliance you place on such information is therefore strictly at your own risk. The creator is not responsible for any incorrect disposal of waste. By using this app, you agree to these terms.

Kitchen & Food.name: Chicken Bones (cooked or raw)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Wrap in newspaper to reduce odors.

Kitchen & Food.name: Cooked Food Leftovers
Kitchen & Food.notes: Wrap in newspaper to absorb moisture.

Kitchen & Food.name: Fish Bones and Skin
Kitchen & Food.notes: Wrap in newspaper to reduce odors.

Kitchen & Food.name: Meat & Fat Scraps
Kitchen & Food.notes: Wrap in newspaper to reduce odors.

Kitchen & Food.name: Aluminium Foil (soiled)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Heavy food contamination prevents recycling.

Kitchen & Food.name: Baking/Parchment Paper
Kitchen & Food.notes: Coated paper that cannot be recycled with normal paper.

Kitchen & Food.name: Broken Crockery (Ceramic, Porcelain)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Broken plates, cups, or bowls. This is not glass.

Kitchen & Food.name: Cooking Oil and Fat (solidified)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Solidify and seal in a container. Do not pour down the drain.

Kitchen & Food.name: Greasy Pizza Box
Kitchen & Food.notes: Grease and food scraps contaminate paper recycling. Clean parts can go in the paper bin.

Kitchen & Food.name: Water Filter Cartridges
Kitchen & Food.notes: Some manufacturers have take-back programs, otherwise it is general waste.

Kitchen & Food.name: Aluminium Foil & Trays (clean)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Must be free of food scraps. Scrunch into a ball.

Kitchen & Food.name: Coffee Capsules (Plastic or Aluminium)
Kitchen & Food.notes: First check if the manufacturer offers a take-back program.

Kitchen & Food.name: Food Tins (food, pet food)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Empty and preferably rinsed.

Kitchen & Food.name: Plastic Bottles (no-deposit: oil, ketchup)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Deposit bottles (Pfandflaschen) should be returned to the store.

Kitchen & Food.name: Yogurt Pots
Kitchen & Food.notes: Ensure it is empty. Rinsing helps prevent odors.

Kitchen & Food.name: Plastic Wrap/Cling Film (soiled)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Heavy food contamination prevents recycling.

Kitchen & Food.name: Wax Paper
Kitchen & Food.notes: Coated paper that cannot be recycled.

Kitchen & Food.name: Takeaway Containers (greasy cardboard)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Grease contaminates paper recycling.

Kitchen & Food.name: Broken Plastic Utensils
Kitchen & Food.notes: Often made of non-recyclable plastic types.

Kitchen & Food.name: Twist Ties
Kitchen & Food.notes: Composite material and too small to be sorted.

Kitchen & Food.name: K-Cups / Coffee Pods (unseparated)
Kitchen & Food.notes: If plastic/aluminum parts are separated from grounds, they can be recycled.

Kitchen & Food.name: Plastic Trays (for meat, fruit)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Must be clean and empty.

Kitchen & Food.name: Squeeze Pouches (for yogurt, baby food)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Ensure they are as empty as possible.

Kitchen & Food.name: Drink Cans (aluminium, steel)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Deposit cans should be returned to the store.

Kitchen & Food.name: Aerosol Cans (food-grade, e.g., whipped cream)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Must be completely empty.

Kitchen & Food.name: Clamshell Containers (plastic)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Must be clean and empty.

Kitchen & Food.name: Pet Food Pouches
Kitchen & Food.notes: Ensure they are empty.

Kitchen & Food.name: Dry Pet Food Bags (plastic-lined paper)
Kitchen & Food.notes: These are composite packaging.

Kitchen & Food.name: Iced Coffee Cups (plastic)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Empty, without lid and straw if possible (those are often Restmüll).

Kitchen & Food.name: Disposable Plastic Plates/Bowls (clean)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Must be clean and free of food.

Kitchen & Food.name: Disposable Plastic Cutlery (clean)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Some regions don't accept them. Check local rules. Must be clean.

Kitchen & Food.name: Fats, oils, and grease (in a sealed container)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Solidify and seal. Do not pour down drain.

Kitchen & Food.name: Disposable coffee cups (coated paper)
Kitchen & Food.notes: The plastic lining makes them non-recyclable with paper.

Kitchen & Food.name: Styrofoam takeout containers (clean)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Must be clean of food residue.

Kitchen & Food.name: Styrofoam takeout containers (soiled)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Food contamination prevents recycling.

Kitchen & Food.name: Broken dishware (glass)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Drinking glasses and dishware have a different composition and melting point than recyclable container glass.

Kitchen & Food.name: Paper towels (used with chemicals)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Chemicals contaminate paper recycling.

Kitchen & Food.name: Spoiled dairy products (e.g. yogurt, sour cream)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Dispose of liquids in toilet, but solids in trash.

Kitchen & Food.name: Paper ice cream containers (plastic-coated)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Plastic coating makes it non-recyclable.

Kitchen & Food.name: Plastic ice cream tubs
Kitchen & Food.notes: Must be empty and clean.

Kitchen & Food.name: Empty condiment packets
Kitchen & Food.notes: Usually composite material and too small to sort.

Kitchen & Food.name: Freezer boxes (for frozen vegetables, etc.)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Cardboard part is recyclable. Inner plastic bag goes to Gelber Sack.

Kitchen & Food.name: Plastic bread tags/clips
Kitchen & Food.notes: Too small to be sorted by recycling machinery.

Kitchen & Food.name: Six-pack rings (plastic)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Cut rings to protect wildlife.

Kitchen & Food.name: Canned food (spoiled)
Kitchen & Food.notes: Empty contents into bio waste, clean and recycle can.

Kitchen & Food.name: Spoiled condiments
Kitchen & Food.notes: Scrape out as much as possible, then dispose of container.

Kitchen & Food.name: Bacon grease
Kitchen & Food.notes: Solidify in a container before disposing.

Kitchen & Food.name: Parchment paper (soiled)
Kitchen & Food.notes: If used for baking and just greasy, it can be composted.

Kitchen & Food.name: Can opener (broken)
Kitchen & Food.notes: If electric. Manual ones are Restmüll.

Paper & Packaging.name: Cereal Boxes
Paper & Packaging.notes: Remove the inner plastic bag (goes in Gelber Sack).

Paper & Packaging.name: Envelopes (with or without window)
Paper & Packaging.notes: The small plastic window does not need to be removed.

Paper & Packaging.name: Wrapping Paper (no glitter/foil)
Paper & Packaging.notes: Paper with glitter, foil, or plastic coating belongs in general waste.

Paper & Packaging.name: Chip Bags & Snack Wrappers
Paper & Packaging.notes: These are often composite materials, but belong in the Gelber Sack.

Paper & Packaging.name: Hardcover Books
Paper & Packaging.notes: The cover and binding are not recyclable. You can tear out the paper pages for the paper bin.

Paper & Packaging.name: Photographs
Paper & Packaging.notes: Coated paper that cannot be recycled with normal paper.

Paper & Packaging.name: Stickers and Backing Paper
Paper & Packaging.notes: Both the sticker and its waxy backing paper are not recyclable.

Paper & Packaging.name: Thermal Paper Receipts
Paper & Packaging.notes: Coated paper that should not be recycled with normal paper.

Paper & Packaging.name: Shredded Paper
Paper & Packaging.notes: Contain in a paper bag to prevent mess.

Paper & Packaging.name: Padded Envelopes (paper only)
Paper & Packaging.notes: If it has bubble wrap lining, it's Restmüll.

Paper & Packaging.name: Plastic Bottles (for water, soda)
Paper & Packaging.notes: Deposit bottles (Pfand) should be returned to a store.

Paper & Packaging.name: Paint Cans (empty and dry)
Paper & Packaging.notes: Must be completely empty and dry. Lids separate.

Paper & Packaging.name: Paper Cups (plastic coated)
Paper & Packaging.notes: The plastic lining prevents recycling with paper.

Paper & Packaging.name: Padded Envelopes (with bubble wrap)
Paper & Packaging.notes: Composite material. Cannot be easily separated.

Paper & Packaging.name: Lottery Tickets/Scratch Cards
Paper & Packaging.notes: The paper part is recyclable, but foil/plastic covering is not.

Paper & Packaging.name: Pizza Box (clean parts)
Paper & Packaging.notes: Tear off any greasy or food-soiled parts (those go to Restmüll).

Paper & Packaging.name: Empty Pill Bottles (plastic)
Paper & Packaging.notes: Remove personal information labels if possible.

Paper & Packaging.name: Packing peanuts (styrofoam)
Paper & Packaging.notes: Although styrofoam packaging is recycled, loose peanuts often are not. Check local rules.

Paper & Packaging.name: Paper liner from food boxes
Paper & Packaging.notes: If soiled with food. If clean, Papiertonne.

Household & Bathroom.name: Baby Wipes
Household & Bathroom.notes: Contain plastic and must not be flushed down the toilet.

Household & Bathroom.name: Broken Drinking Glass
Household & Bathroom.notes: Has a different melting point than container glass. Wrap securely.

Household & Bathroom.name: Broken Incandescent Light Bulb
Household & Bathroom.notes: Wrap carefully. Energy-saving/LED bulbs are e-waste.

Household & Bathroom.name: Cat Litter
Household & Bathroom.notes: Never put in the bio-bin, even if biodegradable. Bag securely.

Household & Bathroom.name: Disposable Razors
Household & Bathroom.notes: Wrap for safety before disposing.

Household & Bathroom.name: Textiles (unwearable)
Household & Bathroom.notes: Rags, single socks, torn clothing. Wearable clothing should be donated.

Household & Bathroom.name: Tissues (used)
Household & Bathroom.notes: For hygiene reasons, these go in general waste.

Household & Bathroom.name: Toothpaste Tubes (empty)
Household & Bathroom.notes: Ensure they are as empty as possible.

Household & Bathroom.name: Dental Floss Containers
Household & Bathroom.notes: Too small to be properly sorted.

Household & Bathroom.name: Nail Polish
Household & Bathroom.notes: Considered household hazardous waste. Take to a collection point.

Household & Bathroom.name: Nail Polish Remover
Household & Bathroom.notes: Hazardous waste due to chemicals.

Household & Bathroom.name: Hair Dye
Household & Bathroom.notes: Chemicals make it hazardous waste.

Household & Bathroom.name: Lint from Dryer
Household & Bathroom.notes: Only if clothes are made of natural fibers (cotton, wool). If synthetic, put in general waste.

Household & Bathroom.name: Old Photographs
Household & Bathroom.notes: Coated paper that can't be recycled.

Household & Bathroom.name: Old CDs and DVDs (unwanted)
Household & Bathroom.notes: Take to a recycling center.

Household & Bathroom.name: CD/DVD Cases
Household & Bathroom.notes: Made of a type of plastic that is not commonly recycled.

Household & Bathroom.name: Mirrors (small, broken)
Household & Bathroom.notes: Wrap carefully.

Household & Bathroom.name: Old clothing
Household & Bathroom.notes: If unwearable. Donate if in good condition.

Household & Bathroom.name: Old shoes
Household & Bathroom.notes: If unwearable. Donate if in good condition.

Household & Bathroom.name: Old credit cards
Household & Bathroom.notes: Cut up for security.

Household & Bathroom.name: Old IDs
Household & Bathroom.notes: Cut up for security.

Household & Bathroom.name: Shattered glass
Household & Bathroom.notes: Wrap carefully in paper before disposing.

Household & Bathroom.name: Old paint brushes
Household & Bathroom.notes: If used with water-based paint. If oil-based, hazardous waste.

Household & Bathroom.name: Wire clothes hangers
Household & Bathroom.notes: Often too thin for recycling facilities. Check with local scrap metal recyclers.

Household & Bathroom.name: Mothballs
Household & Bathroom.notes: Hazardous waste.

Household & Bathroom.name: Fire extinguisher (empty)
Household & Bathroom.notes: Take to a hazardous waste facility or check with fire department.

Household & Bathroom.name: Smoke detector
Household & Bathroom.notes: Contains electronic components and sometimes a small radioactive source.

Household & Bathroom.name: Thermostat (mercury)
Household & Bathroom.notes: Hazardous waste.

Household & Bathroom.name: Ornaments (glass, broken)
Household & Bathroom.notes: Wrap carefully.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Batteries (Alkaline, Rechargeable)
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Return to collection boxes in stores or at recycling centers. DO NOT throw in household waste.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: CDs, DVDs, and Blu-rays
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Many recycling centers have separate collection bins for these.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Mobile Phones / Cell Phones
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Dispose of at a recycling center or participating electronics stores.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: E-Cigarettes and Vapes
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Contain a battery and electronics, must be disposed of as e-waste.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Electric Toothbrush
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: The base unit is e-waste. The brush head is general waste.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Energy-saving Light Bulbs (CFL) & LEDs
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: CFLs contain mercury and must be disposed of as special/e-waste. Do not break.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Ink and Toner Cartridges
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Many stores and manufacturers offer take-back programs. Otherwise, take to a recycling center.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Large Appliances
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Refrigerators, washing machines, ovens. Collected as bulky waste or taken to a recycling center.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Old Medications
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Considered hazardous waste. Return to a pharmacy or dispose of at a hazardous waste collection point. Do not flush!

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Paint Cans (with liquid paint)
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Liquid paint is hazardous waste. Take to a recycling center. Fully dried paint can go in general waste.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Syringes and Needles
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Must be disposed of in a puncture-proof sharps container. Ask local pharmacies or doctor's offices about disposal.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Car Batteries
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Return to auto parts stores or hazardous waste facilities.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Button Cell Batteries
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Common in watches and hearing aids. Return to collection points.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Fluorescent Tubes
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Contain mercury. Handle with care and take to a special collection point.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Thermometers (mercury)
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Hazardous waste. Must be taken to a special collection point.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Pesticides and Herbicides
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Hazardous waste. Take to a special collection point.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Solvents and Thinners
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Hazardous waste. Take to a special collection point.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Motor Oil and Antifreeze
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Hazardous waste. Take to a special collection point or auto shop.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Propane Tanks (empty)
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Take to a hazardous waste facility or participating retailer.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Fire Extinguishers
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Take to a hazardous waste facility or check with the fire department.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Smoke Detectors
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: May contain a small amount of radioactive material. Return to manufacturer or special collection.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Lithium-Ion Batteries
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Handle with care, do not puncture. Take to special collection points.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Nickel-Cadmium Batteries (NiCd)
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Hazardous, take to collection points.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Lead-Acid Batteries
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Hazardous, return to retailer or hazardous waste facility.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Tanning beds
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Check with local bulky waste or special collection.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Refrigerators and Freezers
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Contain coolants that must be handled by professionals.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Air Conditioners
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Contain coolants that must be handled by professionals.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Solar Panels
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Specialized recycling required. Check with installer or local facilities.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Lab equipment
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Check for any hazardous contamination first.

Special & Electronic Waste.name: Medical devices
Special & Electronic Waste.notes: Check for biohazard regulations. Non-contaminated devices are e-waste.

Garden & Outdoors.name: Animal Bedding (herbivores)
Garden & Outdoors.notes: Hay, straw, or bedding from rabbits, guinea pigs, etc.

Garden & Outdoors.name: Branches (small)
Garden & Outdoors.notes: Should be no thicker than a wrist.

Garden & Outdoors.name: Clay/Terracotta Pot (broken)
Garden & Outdoors.notes: In large quantities, dispose of as rubble at a recycling center.

Garden & Outdoors.name: Treated or Painted Wood
Garden & Outdoors.notes: Small pieces can go in general waste, but larger pieces are bulky or hazardous waste.

Garden & Outdoors.name: Bicycle (broken)
Garden & Outdoors.notes: Consider donating or selling it first. Otherwise, it is bulky waste.

Garden & Outdoors.name: Real Christmas Trees
Garden & Outdoors.notes: Check for special local collections after holidays. Remove all decorations.

Garden & Outdoors.name: Wooden Garden Furniture (broken)
Garden & Outdoors.notes: If untreated. Treated wood is hazardous.

Garden & Outdoors.name: Bricks and Concrete (small amounts)
Garden & Outdoors.notes: Check local rules for construction debris.

Garden & Outdoors.name: Asphalt (small amounts)
Garden & Outdoors.notes: Check local rules for construction debris.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Beer Bottles (glass, no-deposit)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Sort by color. Deposit bottles go back to the store.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Cosmetic Jars (glass cream pots)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Empty cream pots, foundation bottles, etc.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Food Jars (jam, pickles, sauces)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Empty and rinsed. Lids go in the Yellow Sack. Sort by color.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Perfume & Cologne Bottles (glass)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Must be empty. Plastic caps go in the Yellow Sack.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Wine Bottles
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Sort by color (clear, green, brown). Lids go in Yellow Sack. Blue glass goes with green glass.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Carpet and Rugs
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Considered bulky waste. Arrange for collection or take to a recycling center.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Furniture (any large piece)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Arrange a collection with your local disposal service or take it to a recycling center.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Large Appliances (fridge, washing machine)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: This is e-waste, but is often collected as bulky waste. Check local rules.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Mattress
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Arrange for a bulky waste collection or take it to a recycling center.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Mirror
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Mirrors are not recyclable with container glass. Dispose of as bulky waste or, if small, as general waste.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Window Pane (broken flat glass)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: This is flat glass, not container glass. Must be disposed of as bulky/construction waste.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Ovenproof Glass Dish (Pyrex)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Has a different melting point than container glass.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Clear Glass
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Goes in the white/clear glass container.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Green Glass
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Goes in the green glass container. Blue glass also goes here.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Brown Glass
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Goes in the brown glass container.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Blue Glass
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Dispose of with green glass.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Lamps (floor, table)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: This is e-waste, but often accepted with bulky waste collection.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Exercise Equipment (treadmill, bike)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Often accepted with bulky waste collection.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Doors
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Considered construction debris.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Windows
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Considered construction debris.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Musical Instruments (large, e.g., piano)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Check for specialty recycling or donation options first.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Sinks and Toilets
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Ceramic. Considered construction debris.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Grills / BBQs
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Remove propane tank (hazardous waste).

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Aquariums / Fish Tanks (glass)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Not recyclable with container glass.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Blinds and Shades
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: If too large for bin, dispose as bulky waste.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Pallets (wood)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Check for local pallet recycling programs first.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Tires
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Special disposal required. Take to a garage or tire shop.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Wood (treated, painted)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Hazardous waste.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Drywall / Plasterboard
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Construction debris.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Insulation
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Construction debris. May be hazardous.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Roofing Shingles
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Construction debris.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Siding
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Construction debris.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Broken Glass Bottles/Jars
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Handle with care.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Light Bulbs (incandescent)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Not recyclable with container glass.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Window Glass
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Flat glass is not recycled with container glass.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Auto Glass / Windshields
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Specialty laminated glass.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Crystal Glass
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Contains lead.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Lab Glass (beakers, flasks)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Often borosilicate (Pyrex type).

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Glass Tabletop
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Flat glass.

Glass & Bulky Items.name: Shelving (glass)
Glass & Bulky Items.notes: Flat glass.

articles.title: Find Glass Containers
content: For bottles and jars without deposit, sorted by color.

articles.title: Find E-waste Collection Points
content: For old electronics, batteries, and devices.

articles.title: Find Clothing Containers
content: For wearable clothes and shoes.

articles.title: Find Bottle Deposit Return Points
content: Return deposit bottles (Pfand system) at most supermarkets.
articles.mapQuery: Supermarket with bottle return machine nearby

articles.title: E-Waste
content: Any device with a plug or battery is e-waste.
Return them to electronics stores or a recycling center (Wertstoffhof).
This includes phones, laptops, kettles, and even electric toothbrushes.

articles.title: Hazardous Waste (Schadstoffe)
content: Includes liquid paint, chemicals, pesticides, and mercury thermometers.
Must be taken to a hazardous waste collection vehicle (Schadstoffmobil) or recycling center.
Never pour down the drain or put in household bins.

articles.title: Medication Disposal
content: Old pills and liquids are hazardous waste.
Return them to a pharmacy for safe disposal.
Do not flush them down the toilet.

articles.title: Bulky Waste (Sperrmüll)
content: Items too large for your bin, like furniture, carpets, and mattresses.
Schedule a pickup with your local municipality or take them to a recycling center.
E-waste and construction rubble are often handled separately.

articles.title: Reduce and Reuse
content: Use reusable shopping bags, coffee cups, and water bottles.
Buy products with minimal packaging.
Repair items instead of replacing them.

articles.title: The Green Dot (Der Grüne Punkt)
content: This symbol indicates the manufacturer has contributed to the cost of packaging recycling.
It doesn't necessarily mean the item is recyclable, but most items with this symbol are.

articles.title: Pfand System
content: Germany has a very effective deposit-return (Pfand) system for beverage containers.
Return them to a reverse vending machine at a supermarket to get your deposit back.
